''[[Hallelujah! (TV series)|Hallelujah!]]'' }} '''Patricia Amy "Patsy" Rowlands''' (19 January 1931 – 22 January 2005){{Cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4203011.stm | title=BBC News - Carry On Star Patsy Rowlands dies | accessdate=21 November 2013 }}{{Cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4203011.stm | title=Patsy Rowlands - Obituaries - The Independent | accessdate=21 November 2013 }} was an [[English people|English]] [[actress]] who is best remembered for her roles in the [[Carry On (franchise)|''Carry On'' films]] series, and as Betty Lewis in the popular [[ITV Thames]] sitcom ''[[Bless This House (UK TV series)|Bless This House]]'', and as Alice Meredith in the [[Yorkshire Television]] sitcom ''[[Hallelujah! (TV series)|Hallelujah!]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Patsy-Rowlands|title=Patsy Rowlands - British actress|publisher=}} ==Early years== She was born in Palmers Green, London and attended the Sacred Heart [[convent]] school at Whetstone. While attending, an [[elocution]] teacher spotted her potential and encouraged her to pursue a career in acting. She applied for the [[Guildhall School of Music and Drama]], and won a scholarship aged fifteen. ==Early career== Rowlands began her career in the chorus of ''[[Annie Get Your Gun (musical)|Annie Get Your Gun]]'', followed by a summer season in [[Torquay]]. She then spent several years with the [[Players' Theatre]] in London, before making her West End debut in [[Sandy Wilson]]'s musical ''[[Valmouth]]''. It was at this time she met her future husband, the composer [[Malcolm Sircom]]. They divorced in 1967.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Other [[West End theatre]] credits included ''Semi-Detached'' with [[Laurence Olivier]] and directed by [[Tony Richardson]] (with whom she was to work often, appearing in his 1963 film [[Tom Jones (1963 film)|Tom Jones]]), ''Shut Your Eyes and Think of England'', with [[Donald Sinden]], ''[[The Seagull]]'' and [[Ben Travers]]'s ''The Bed Before Yesterday'', both directed by [[Lindsay Anderson]] and ''When We Are Married'' for [[Ronald Eyre]].https://www.nytimes.com/2005/01/30/obituaries/patsy-rowlands-actress-in-the-carry-on-comedies-dies-at-71.html?mcubz=0 She also starred in [[Cameron Mackintosh]]'s revival of ''[[Oliver!]]'' in the mid-1990s, as well as playing Jack's mother in the original London cast of Sondheim's ''[[Into the Woods]]''.{{cite web|url=https://theatricalia.com/person/13d0/patsy-rowlands|title=Patsy Rowlands - Theatricalia|website=theatricalia.com}} Her final appearance was as Mrs Pearce in the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]]'s production of ''My Fair Lady'' which also starred [[Jonathan Pryce]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2001/legit/reviews/my-fair-lady-6-1200467240/|title=Review: ‘My Fair Lady’|first=Matt|last=Wolf|date=21 March 2001|publisher=}} Rowlands also appeared in film and TV versions of two of [[Frances Hodgson Burnett]]'s books: "Little Lord Fauntleroy" and "A Little Princess."{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b739b7cf7|title=Little Lord Fauntleroy (1980)|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b739d5f31|title=A Little Princess Part 5 (1987)|publisher=}} In the 1980 TV movie "[[Little Lord Fauntleroy (1980 film)|Little Lord Fauntleroy]]," with Alec Guinness (as Earl of Dorincourt) and Ricky Schroder (as "Ceddy", Little Lord Fauntleroy), she played a village lady named Mrs. Dibble.{{cite web|title=Little Lord Fauntleroy 1980 TV Movie|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0081062/fullcredits?ref_=tt_ov_st_sm|website=IMDb|accessdate=30 January 2016}} In the BBC production of the 1986 TV miniseries "[[A Little Princess (1986 miniseries)|A Little Princess]]," she played the role of the "Baker's Wife," who gives Sara 6 buns for fourpence and later takes under her wing a homeless beggar girl Sara had befriended.{{cite web|title=A Little Princess Full Cast and Crew|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090474/fullcredits?ref_=tt_ov_st_sm|website=IMDb|accessdate=30 January 2016}} Rowlands also appeared quite frequently on television early in her career. Amongst the various series in which she appeared, were several appearances in ''[[Gert and Daisy#Film, radio and television|Gert and Daisy]]'' (1959) as Bonnie, as well as appearing in 2 episodes of ''[[Danger Man]]'' (as different, unrelated characters) and in ''[[The Avengers (TV series)|The Avengers]]'' episode "Love All".{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b9f4e8b23|title=Patsy Rowlands|publisher=}}http://danger-man.co.uk/episodeDetails.asp?episodeID=57&seriesNo=4{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/avengers-love-all-v182515/cast-crew|title=Avengers: Love All (1969) - Peter Sykes - Cast and Crew - AllMovie|website=AllMovie}} Rowlands played the role of a love interest for George called "Beryl" in the 1979 Christmas special and final episode of ''[[George and Mildred]]'' ==''Carry On'' films== She made her debut in the ''[[Carry On (franchise)|Carry On]]'' films in ''[[Carry On Again Doctor]]'' in 1969 and soon became a regular member of the team, usually playing the dowdy, put-upon wife or the long-suffering secretary.{{cite web|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/features/obituaries/2005/patsy-rowlands/|title=Patsy Rowlands - Obituaries - The Stage|date=1 February 2005|publisher=}} Between 1969 and 1975 she appeared in nine of the films in increasingly large roles, appearing in [[Carry On Again Doctor]], [[Carry On Loving]], [[Carry On Henry]], [[Carry On Matron]], [[Carry On Abroad]] and [[Carry On Dick]] - more substantial roles include [[Carry On At Your Convenience]], [[Carry On Girls]] and [[Carry On Behind]]. On 7 March 1971 she starred in a single episode ''(You've Really Landed Me In It This Time)'' of popular ITV sitcom ''[[Doctor at Large (TV series)|Doctor at Large]]'', with [[Barry Evans (actor)|Barry Evans]] and [[George Layton]], as a nymphomaniac secretary, a role she seemed to relish and had played similarly in ''[[Carry On Loving]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b87348aa3|title=You've Really Landed Me in It This Time (1971)|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://carryonfan.blogspot.co.uk/2017/01/patsy-rowlands-her-carry-on-story.html|title=Patsy Rowlands: Her Carry On Story|website=carryonfan.blogspot.co.uk}} From 1971 to 1976, she played Betty, the feckless neighbour in the popular ITV sitcom ''[[Bless This House (UK TV series)|Bless This House]]'', which starred fellow Carry On star [[Sid James]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aveleyman.com/ActorCredit.aspx?ActorID=15048|title=Patsy Rowlands|website=www.aveleyman.com}} Her other television credits at this time included appearances with comedians such as [[Les Dawson]] and [[Dick Emery]]. In the early 1980s, she appeared with [[Thora Hird]] in the sitcom ''[[Hallelujah! (TV series)|Hallelujah!]]'', in which they played an aunt and niece in [[The Salvation Army]]. In 1991 she appeared in an episode of ''[[Zorro (1990 TV series)|Zorro]]'' filmed in [[Madrid, Spain]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0755199/|title=Miracle of the Pueblo|date=8 December 1991|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newworldzorro.com/presskitinfo/prodnotes.html|title=New World Zorro Production Notes|website=www.newworldzorro.com}}{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} ==Later years== Towards the end of her life, Rowlands appeared in several revivals of major [[musicals]] such as ''[[Oliver!]]'' at the [[London Palladium]] and ''[[My Fair Lady]]'' at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]].{{cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/patsy-rowlands-1-672697|title=Patsy Rowlands|website=www.scotsman.com}} Later television credits include ''[[The Cazalets]]'', ''[[The Canterbury Tales]]'', ''[[The Cater Street Hangman#Film.2C TV or theatrical adaptations|The Cater Street Hangman]]'', ''[[Get Well Soon (TV series)|Get Well Soon]]'', ''[[Vanity Fair (1998 TV serial)|Vanity Fair]]'', ''Murder Most English'', and ''[[Bottom (TV series)|Bottom]]'' for the [[BBC]]. In 2002, she was a guest on the paranormal series ''[[Most Haunted]]''. Rowlands took part in several DVD audio commentaries along with other surviving stars of the ''Carry On'' films in 2003.{{Cite web | url=http://www.robertross.co.uk/page5.htm | title=Robert Ross DVD | accessdate=21 November 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131205202023/http://www.robertross.co.uk/page5.htm | archivedate=5 December 2013 | df=dmy-all }} ==Death== Rowlands developed [[breast cancer]] and had to abandon her plans to become an acting teacher, and quietly retire. She died of the disease in an [[East Sussex]] [[Hospice care|hospice]], three days after her 74th birthday. She was survived by her only son, Alan (born 1963).{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2005/jan/26/guardianobituaries.film | title=Patsy Rowlands | first=Dennis | last=Barker | newspaper=The Guardian | date=26 January 2005 | accessdate=15 July 2012}} ==Television roles== ===Comedy=== {| class="wikitable" !
